title: Is electrical current considered only to be a flow of just electrons? - Quora

response.answer_text: FULL QUESTION: “Some definitions say that electrical current is a flow of electrons. Some definitions say that electrical current can be a flow of charge particles such as electrons, protons, ions, holes etc. Is the latter definition right as well?” The books claiming that all electric currents are electron flows, those are for kids, and also for repair-techs. They’re wrong. Their simplified statements are called “lies to children,” such as teaching that atoms are just like tiny solar systems, or that Christopher Columbus was a heroic saint who was the first to discover America. Adults later learn the uncomfortable truths! Textbooks intended for scientists and engineers won’t try to teach the childhood concepts, such as: veinous blood is bright blue, or your tongue has flavor-detecting areas, or that atoms look like tiny six-petal flowers seen in those 1950s films about atomic power. Instead they’ll tell you about +H hydrogen ion currents in biochemistry and in battery acid. The +H hydrogen ion has another name: it’s called a proton. Proton electric currents are +H ion flows. Inside car batteries, down in the acid, the hundreds of amperes are a flow of protons. Inside human bodies (with medical electrodes attached?) the currents are flows of non-electron charges: positive sodiums and potassiums and +H ions, negative chlorides and -OH ions. No electrons. What then is the full, correct meaning of “electric current?” Better not listen to books aimed at the non-scientist!

Electric current is the flow of charge. That is it. Electrical circuit theory does not concern itself with what carries the charge. Different kinds of charged particles have different parameters in the context of current like mobility and relaxation time, but their effects are modeled by equations like[math] E=jρ[/math], and the only thing the symbol “i” stands for is the flow of charge [math]dq/dt[/math]. Current arises due to different charge carriers, but the current itself is the same. For example, in a transistor (the bipolar ones), we have to add the current due to electrons and the current due to the holes to get the total current. I[math] [/math][math]= Ie + Ih[/math] Also, this current will flow as lithium ions or sulphate ions if we connect it to a battery. Even in an antimatter universe, our curcuit theory will remain the same, because current due to positrons is still current.

In that the concept of electrical current is a man-made definition, it can be whatever we want it to be, so long as we agree on the same definition. However, I would agree that any net flow of charge constitutes an electrical current. As long as charges, positive or negative, are streaming from one place to another, that, in my opinion, constitutes an current. However, for a huge number of purposes such as electrical power or computers, the only kind of current that matters is the flow of electrons. People working in such areas will not bother considering all the other forms of current, because they don’t matter to them in their everyday life.

Any movement of electrically charged particles is considered current. The direction of electrical current is defined by direction positively charged particles which is opposite of actual movement of electrons through wires. Normally electrons can freely move while atoms can move only in gas and air, but are slower. In fact, in chemical batteries, or electrolytic solutions the current in the electrolyte is a result of movement of ions from the positive terminal to the negative terminal for positive radicals and vice versa for negative radicals and is carried in fact, because electrolytes are easily ionised in certain solutions.
